title: Phoenix hires WH Smith chair Henry Staunton as it prepares for more deals
text:

Thu, Aug 20, 2015, 14:47 BST - UK Markets close in 1 hr 43 mins Phoenix hires WH Smith chair Henry Staunton as it prepares for more deals By Marion Dakers | Telegraph – 1 hour 11 minutes ago -6.4000 
Insurance consolidator expects to buy more pension books once capital rules are clearer 
Henry Staunton is adding a second FTSE 250 chairmanship to his workload, after agreeing to replace Sir Howard Davies as the chair of the pensions consolidation business Phoenix Group. 
Mr Staunton, who also chairs WH Smith (LSE: SMWH.L - news ) and the private rent-to-own retailer Bright House, will take up his new post on September 1. 
His career has included almost two decades in finance roles at ITV (LSE: ITV.L - news ) , which saw him play a key role in the £2.6bn merger of Granada and Carlton in 2004. As well as his chairmanships, he currently holds non-executive roles at the insurance group Legal & General (LSE: LGEN.L - news ) , Capital & Counties Properties (LSE: CAPC.L - news ) and Standard Bank. 
The appointment comes as Sir Howard departs to chair Royal Bank of Scotland (LSE: RBS.L - news ) . 
“I am delighted we have appointed such an experienced chairman, who has played a key role in the development of so many other businesses,” said Clive Bannister, chief executive, on Thursday. 
Phoenix (LSE: PHNX.L - news ) , which was set up to consolidate and run closed pension schemes more efficiently, reported a 50pc fall in operating profit to £135m in the first six months of the year but said cash generation was on track. 
The firm generated £110m in the first-half, down from a year ago as the group prepared to comply with the forthcoming Solvency II rules on capital , but on course to reach £200m to £250m over the course of 2015. 
Phoenix, like other UK insurers, is awaiting approval for its capital model from the Prudential Regulation Authority ahead of the new rules coming into effect in January. 
The group won its first investment-grade rating from Fitch Ratings earlier this month, enabling it to lower its debt costs and pay for deal-making through funds raised in the capital markets. 
Mr Bannister said Phoenix was scouting further takeovers, despite a pause in the market while insurers are preoccupied with capital levels. “We said there would be a hiatus while Solvency II comes through. People don’t know the value of what they are buying or what they are selling, and the capital requirements associated with them,” he said. 
“We remain convinced that the reasons that people will sell their business remain true: the need for capital, and specialised skills.” 
= Pension changes = 
Phoenix has felt the effect of new freedoms for pensioners , which have knocked sales of ordinary annuities as savers look for more flexible ways to deploy their retirement funds. Phoenix’s sales of ordinary annuities to pensioners on its books fell 47pc on last year, while demand remained strong for enhanced or guaranteed annuities, which offer better rates for certain savers. 
About 15,000 Phoenix customers have asked to cash out their entire pension scheme, with an average pot size of £13,000. 
Phoenix kept its dividend payment at 26.7p per share.
